Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Live according to Christian moral values and ethics
Situation2: They encounter choices where Christian ethics become more relevant
Story: I sat at the edge of the living room, my hands folded tightly in my lap as my mother explained the importance of the upcoming ancestral ceremony. “You’re the eldest daughter now,” she said, her eyes shining with hope. “It’s your turn to lead the prayers and offerings, just as our family has done for generations.” I nodded, feeling the weight of her expectations settle on my shoulders. I knew how much this meant to her, to all of them. But as she described the rituals—bowing before the ancestral altar, offering food, and reciting words I’d learned as a child—I felt a knot form in my stomach. My faith as a Christian taught me to worship only God, to avoid rituals that felt like worshipping ancestors. The thought of disappointing my family made my chest ache, but so did the idea of betraying my beliefs. I could see the pride in my mother’s face, the anticipation in my relatives’ voices, and I felt torn in two, caught between honoring my family and staying true to my faith.
